title: Many Democrats Just Aren’t Buying It From Billionaires
content:
MANCHESTER , N.H.—Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg has devoted millions of dollars of his personal wealth to campaigns to curb gun violence and address climate change . He has often cast his fortune in virtuous terms when it comes to politics , noting the degree of independence it gave him while he served a dozen years as mayor .
“ Americans want elected officials to put partisanship aside and work together on real solutions to their problems because they see these problems all around them , ” Mr. Bloomberg said Tuesday during a breakfast appearance at the New Hampshire Institute of Politics , at Saint Anselm College .
How to Prepare for a Presidential Run : The 2020 To-Do List Presidential hopefuls are stepping out of the shadows , but their 2020 announcements are far from spontaneous . WSJ ’ s Shelby Holliday explains .
But as he determines whether to run for president , the 76-year-old businessman and philanthropist is facing a nagging question at the start of the 2020 campaign : Can a billionaire competing in the Trump era win the hearts and minds of Democrats ?
Mr. Bloomberg , describing his presidential deliberations after a tour of a metal parts factory in Nashua , N.H. , said his exchanges with voters here would give him “ an instinctive feel of whether you can relate , whether you really understand what they want , need and whether I think I can do something about it . ”
Later , after stopping at a restaurant in Dover , N.H. , he was asked whether Democrats have an appetite for another billionaire . “ I don ’ t know—that ’ s what the electoral process is all about , ” he said .
Some of his opponents already are energizing activists by promoting tougher Wall Street regulations and others have devised tax increases on the wealthiest Americans as a counter to President Trump ’ s tax overhaul . Some have already called on billionaire candidates—an obvious reference to Mr. Bloomberg—to refrain from self-funding their Democratic campaigns .
“ In a Democratic primary where multiple candidates have staked out ground on raising taxes on the super-wealthy , Bloomberg risks being their foil and punching bag , ” said Chris Kofinis , a Democratic strategist . “ If you ’ re one of the candidates running a populist campaign , Bloomberg will become a target you will not avoid . ”
Mr. Bloomberg sought to separate himself from fellow billionaire and former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz , who said in a “ 60 Minutes ” interview that he was considering an independent presidential campaign .
Mr. Bloomberg , who considered running for president as an independent in 2016 , told reporters : “ No . 1 , you can ’ t win as an independent because the Electoral College requires a majority and No . 2 , I think all it would do would be to re-elect Donald Trump . ”
One billionaire has already bowed out from the campaign . Tom Steyer , a longtime environmental activist , said in early January he wouldn ’ t run , concluding he could have more influence by pressing for Mr. Trump ’ s impeachment .
Kevin Mack , an adviser to Mr. Steyer , said that “ some segments of the party will be automatically against you if you are wealthy. ” But he said primary voters would be open to a candidate who used his or her wealth to promote good causes .
“ If you allow yourself to be defined solely as a billionaire , it ’ s not going to go well , ” Mr. Mack said . “ But if you tell your story about how you made your money and what you did with your money , people will listen . ”
Advisers to Mr. Bloomberg have polled likely Democratic primary voters in recent weeks and determined that voters would be comfortable with a candidate whose wealth was self-made , according to a person familiar with the discussions . The person said the polling also found it “ matters enormously ” to primary voters to know that a wealthy candidate had supported philanthropic causes .
In New Hampshire , Mr. Bloomberg said whether he runs for president or not he will seek to build support for a “ Green New Deal ” to help fight climate change . He said Democrats should begin offering specific ways to accomplish that—and said he was working on a plan of his own .
“ I ’ m a little bit tired of listening to things that are ‘ pie in the sky , ’ that we never are going to pass , that we ’ re never going to afford , ” Mr. Bloomberg said . “ I think it ’ s disingenuous to promote those things . You have to do something that ’ s practical . ”
Mr. Bloomberg has maintained an active schedule in recent weeks , addressing his work on climate change and gun control and noting his own nonpartisan brand .
“ I ’ ve never been a partisan guy . In fact , I ’ ve been a Democrat , a Republican ... an independent and a Democrat again . So if there is anyone who is an expert on party politics , it is me , ” he said during a speech to the U.S. Conference of Mayors in Washington last week .
An Iowa poll conducted by The Des Moines Register in mid-December of Democratic likely caucus-goers found that Mr. Bloomberg was viewed favorably by 40 % and unfavorably by 31 % .
An informal survey of 21 Iowa Democratic county chairmen by The Wall Street Journal found this week that 12 would be amenable to supporting a billionaire or a self-funding Democratic candidate . Nine said they would not .
“ Americans have seen what a billionaire has done to this country , ” said Rosemary Schwartz , the Democratic chairwoman in Benton County . “ After Trump , I would have to think twice . ”
Brigham Hoegh , the Democratic chairwoman in Audubon County , said she could support a billionaire candidate but added : “ I think such candidates really have to work to appear in touch with voters . ”
Mr. Bloomberg ’ s potential rivals are already laying the groundwork for the party to push strongly against the influence of billionaires .
Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren told MSNBC ’ s Rachel Maddow in an interview this month that primary voters should say “ no to the billionaires whether they are self-funding or whether they are funding PACs . ”
The senator last week proposed a 2 % annual tax on household wealth above $ 50 million and an additional 1 % tax on wealth above $ 1 billion .
New York Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand , who has announced her candidacy , urged supporters in a Friday email to “ tell every candidate running for office to reject money from corporate PACs , federal lobbyists and super PACs—and to cease self-funding . ”
Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders , who is mulling a second presidential campaign , has frequently criticized billionaires such as the Walton family , which founded Walmart Inc. , and Amazon.com Inc. CEO Jeff Bezos .
During an event in Toronto earlier this month , Mr. Bloomberg noted the benefits of not having to raise money for his campaigns .
“ The mayor ’ s office was at one end of City Hall and the City Council was at the other end of City Hall and the door was in the middle , ” Mr. Bloomberg said . “ Every lobbyist came into that , through that front door , turned right . They never turned left because they knew they just weren ’ t going to get any business . ”
Mr. Bloomberg ’ s allies note his years of work on an array of issues and his willingness to spend his own money to advance policy ideas and Democratic candidates in the 2018 midterm elections .
Louisville Mayor Greg Fischer , who attended the mayors ’ conference , said Mr. Bloomberg had “ demonstrated he knows how to lead , he knows how to manage , he has the resources to put together incredible teams . ”
Asked if it was detrimental to be a billionaire candidate in the party , Mr. Fischer , a Democrat , said : “ If people are simplistic enough to put one label on a person . Mike Bloomberg has a lot of labels . Philanthropist , innovator , social change agent . Look what he ’ s done on gun safety issues . So he has an extremely progressive record as well . ”
